body: I think it should be "may be undefined" in both cases. IMO the general rule is roughly like this: if mypy can prove it will always fail, it is "use before definition", and if mypy cannot prove it will not fail, it is "may be undefined". So it is fine to have some false negatives for the first, and some false positives for the second. But not vice versa.

I agree with the thought behind this (when to use which error code). 

However, I'm a bit worried that it will generate too many false positives and I'm thinking that maybe we should explicitly assume that everything from outer scope is always defined, even if definition comes after.

I recently stumbled upon an interesting example:
```python
class C:
    def f0(self) -> None:
        self.f1()  # If we report cross-scope errors, this will be a `partially-defined` error.
    def f1(self) -> None:
        pass
```
So for the example with classes above, we will definitely need some special handling (make class scope special). I'm not convinced that the noise is worth it.

The example with method is obviously safe, but attribute access is totally different story and will require separate handling independently of what we do here.

Coming back to variables, the `partially-defined` error code is going to stay off by default, so people who will opt in to it, will likely prefer false positives over false negatives (especially if there is a simple workaround like put variables at top of module). As a random data point, I have fixed a bad bug caused by use of a forward global ~year ago.

Note however, code like this should not generate any errors:
```python
def foo() -> None:
    bar()

def bar() -> None:
    foo()
```
Because this is actually a very common pattern, and a totally fine one. If it is hard to implement the global variable error without also causing an error in this last example, it is fine to leave it as a follow up issue. (But we definitely should not give the `use-before-def` error as we currently do.)

issue.title: [partially defined] fix false positive with global/nonlocal vars
issue.body:
This is a workaround until we implement better handling for variables undefined in global scope (see #14213).

We treat `global/nonlocal` as a variable declaration. I've included test cases that should fail in the future once we implement the check properly.

body: The check is a bit non-trivial to implement (since we need to handle var vs def declaration in scope differently). For now, #14222 will make it not generate an error.

issue.title: Enable use-before-def error code by default
issue.body:
This enables the error code added in #14163.

We aren't sure if it will cause too many problems. We can see what the mypy primer outputs as well.

body:
After #14517 is merged, this issue will largely be resolved.
We still don't detect the following case:
```python
def foo() -> None:
  global x
  print(x)  # No error here right now.

foo()  # This will result in a runtime error.
x = 1
```

But I don't see how we can handle this in a reasonable way. We either need to flag all such uses as possibly-undefined (which will cause a *ton* of errors -- any time you're using a global var). Or we'll need to track the order in which functions are called (which seems very difficult to implement).
Yes, I think this issue can be closed by #14517. You can either open a separate (low-priority) issue to track the remaining tricky case, or just wait for someone to complain about this :-)

issue.title: [used before def] improve handling of global definitions in local scopes
issue.body:
While working on #14483, we discovered that variable inheritance didn't work quite right. In particular, functions would inherit variables from outer scope. On the surface, this is what you want but actually, they only inherit the scope if there isn't a colliding definition within that scope.

Here's an example:
```python
class c: pass

def f0() -> None:
    s = c()  # UnboundLocalError is raised when this code is executed.
    class c: pass

def f1() -> None:
    s = c()  # No error.
```
This PR also fixes issues with builtins (exactly the same example as above but instead of `c` we have a builtin).

Fixes #14213 (as much as is reasonable to do)
